thread.title: Baseball roundup: Angels beat Rangers, 2-1, to stay in wild-card hunt - Baseball
thread.title_full: Baseball roundup: Angels beat Rangers, 2-1, to stay in wild-card hunt - Baseball - NorthJersey.com

author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS |
title: Baseball roundup: Angels beat Rangers, 2-1, to stay in wild-card hunt - Baseball
text:
Buy this photo ASSOCIATED PRESS Jered Weaver allows one run on two hits in six innings Friday for the Angels. Mike Trout hit a leadoff triple in the ninth inning and scored on Albert Pujols’ tiebreaking single, sending the wild card-contending Los Angeles Angels to a 2-1 win over Texas that kept the Rangers from clinching the AL West title Friday night in Arlington, Texas.
Rangers closer Shawn Tolleson (6-4) appeared in his fourth consecutive game. Trout hit the second pitch deep into the right-center gap, then slid headfirst into third base before emphatically pumping his right arm toward his teammates in the dugout.
Buy this photo Pujols followed with a soft single to left field on the next pitch.
Texas went into Friday already assured a playoff spot, but able to secure the division title with a win over the Angels or a loss by second-place Houston.
Mike Morin (4-2), the fourth Angels pitcher, retired the only batter he faced when Adrian Beltre grounded out to end the eighth.
Joe Smith worked a perfect ninth for his fourth save, including a strikeout of slugger Josh Hamilton.
Jered Weaver, making his 20th career start at Texas, allowed two hits over six innings. The right-hander struck out two and walked three.
ROYALS 3, TWINS 1 (at Minneapolis) — Ben Zobrist put a major dent in Minnesota’s postseason bid with an RBI double in the eighth inning against struggling All-Star Glen Perkins, and Kansas City topped the Twins.
Perkins, hampered by neck and back trouble that led to his removal from the closer role, spoiled a stellar start by Ervin Santana (7-5) with a first-pitch fastball that Zobrist drove off the wall in right-center field. Zobrist then scored when right fielder Torii Hunter fumbled a single by Mike Moustakas.
Chris Young gave the defending AL champion Royals another reason to consider him for the postseason rotation, allowing an RBI single by Aaron Hicks in the third. The 36-year-old gave up four hits in 6 1/3 innings, retiring 15 out of 16 batters at one point.
BLUE JAYS 8, RAYS 4 (at St. Petersburg., Fla.) — Troy Tulowitzki doubled and singled in his return to the Toronto lineup after missing three weeks with injuries, and the Blue Jays rallied past Tampa Bay.
Edwin Encarnacion and Russell Martin homered for the Jays, who stayed tied with Kansas City in the race for the AL’s best record and home-field advantage throughout the postseason.
Mark Buehrle (15-7) gave up four runs and six hits in 6 2/3 innings.
PIRATES 6, REDS 4, 12 inns. (at Pittsburgh) — Starling Marte hit his 19th homer after Gregory Polanco walked with one out in the 12th and Pittsburgh beat Cincinnati to stay two games in front of the Cubs for the right to host Wednesday’s wild card game.
Joey Votto tied a Reds record by reaching base safely in his 48th consecutive game. Votto singled in the third inning Friday night off Pittsburgh Pirates left-hander Francisco Liriano to match Pete Rose’s mark set in 1978.
WHITE SOX 2, TIGERS 1 (at Chicago) — Chris Sale allowed one run over seven-plus innings and set a White Sox season strikeout record as Chicago beat Detroit.
By getting James McCann looking at a 3-2 breaking ball for the first out of the second inning, Sale struck out his 270th batter of the season. 
He began the game with 267 strikeouts and broke the mark set by Hall of Famer Ed Walsh in 1908 when he struck out 269 batters.
Earlier Friday, White Sox GM Rick Hahn said he expected manager Robin Ventura to return, and also announced the team would not be retaining bench coach Mark Parent after the end of a disappointing season.
CUBS 6, BREWERS 1 (at Milwaukee) — Jake Arrieta (22-6, 1.77 ERA) struck out seven in six strong innings, and Chicago beat Milwaukee. Anthony Rizzo had two hits and three RBI, including a solo homer.
NATIONALS SKIPPER WILLIAMS OUT? CBSsports.com’s Jon Heyman reported that Nationals manager Matt Williams will be fired at the end of the season. The Nationals (81-78) sit eight games behind the Mets, and the final straw probably was Williams’ mishandling of the embarrassing dugout incident between star Bryce Harper and closer Jonathan Papelbon.
